thread.title: HU women end volleyball slide at 17 matches with win at Norfolk State
thread.title_full: HU women end volleyball slide at 17 matches with win at Norfolk State

title: HU women end volleyball slide at 17 matches with win at Norfolk State
text:
HU women end volleyball slide at 17 matches with win at Norfolk State Daily Press 
COLLEGES: 
Women’s volleyball: 
After starting the season 0-17, Hampton broke through by edging Norfolk State 25-19, 25-27, 29-27, 27-29, 15-11 Friday night at Echols Hall. 
Brianna Lilly had 51 assists and 23 digs for HU, while Reeana Richardson had 21 kills. Darcy Moore had 51 assists and five digs for NSU. ... 
Virginia Tech (13-6, 4-3 ACC) breezed past Clemson 25-19, 25-19, 25-17 as Lindsey Owens had 13 kills and seven digs. 
Men’s soccer: 
Wesley Wade scored the night's final two goals as No. 11 Virginia (8-3-2, 3-2-1 ACC) beat visiting Pittsburgh 3-1 despite trailing at halftime to the Panthers (5-6-3, 0-5-1). 
Edward Opoku netted the tying goal. ... 
Virginia Tech (5-5-3, 0-0-3 ACC) played No. 8 Notre Dame to a 0-0 tie oer 110 minutes in Blacksburg, in which the goalkeepers — Tech’s Ben Lundgaard and Notre Dame’s Chris Hubbard — had just two saves apiece. 
The Irish went to 8-2-4, 3-1-3. 
Women’s soccer: 
William and Mary (10-3-1, 4-1 CAA) blanked Drexel 2-0 in Philadelphia, clinching its NCAA-record 35th straight winning season. The Tribe never has finished at .500 or below. 
Junior Clara Logsdon and sophomore Sami Grasso scored to beat the Dragons (7-8, 1-5). ... 
Deirdre Bradley’s header 1:13 into overtime lifted Old Dominion (6-9, 4-2 Conference USA) to a 2-1 home win over Charlotte. The Monarchs tied the score with just 1:20 left in regulation on Madison Hogan’s goal off Kathryn Hill’s assist. 
Women’s cross country: 
No. 23 William and Mary finished ahead of four higher-ranked teams in the Wisconsin Adidas Invitational and placed 16th among 36 teams with 464 points. 
Senior Regan Rome paced W&M by placing ninth in the 6-kilometer race in 19:54.4, and No. 1 New Mexico easily won the team title with 32 points, followed by No. 11 Arkansas at 188. No. 17 Virginia placed third with 217 points. 
Men’s cross country: 
W&M was last in the elite 36-team Wisconsin Adidas Invitational field, though every runner showed significant improvement its performance in Madison, Wis., a year ago. The Tribe was led by Faris Sakallah in 24:49.7 for 8K. 
Field hockey: 
Drexel (5-8, 2-1 CAA) won 1-0 over W&M (5-9, 1-3) in Philadelphia on Lindsay Boerner’s rebound goal with about 14 minutes remaining. 
Women’s tennis: 
W&M’s Olivia Thaler and ODU’s Nikol Hristova and Nataliya Vlasova earned first-round singles victories at the Intercollegiate Tennis Association Atlantic Regional in Lynchburg. 
So did numerous U.Va. players, including Victoria Olivarez from Virginia Beach. Other Cavaliers to advance included Maci Epstein, Susi, Kelley, Skylar Morton and Stephanie Nauta.Virginia Tech players to win first-rounders included Elena Cerezo-Codina, Francesca Fusinato, Caroline Daxhelet, Kelly Williford and Katherine Butler. 
Hampton’s Cherise Slocombe and Kristina Titova registered a round-of-32 doubles victory, as did Norfolk State’s Dajana Cvjetkovic and Liza Gordeeva and ODU’s Nikol Hristova and Marijana Novakovic. 
U.Va. tandems advancing included Olivarez-Maci Epstein and Danielle Collins-Meghan Kelley. Tech combinations moving into the doubles round of 16 included Fusinato-Williford, Cerezo-Codina –Daxhelet and Raluca Mita-Ilinca Stoica. ... 
Emory’s Bridget Harding and Katarina Su beat Mary Washington’s Shelby Harris of Newport News and Kait Brogan 6-1, 6-2 in an ITA Small College National Championships Division III women’s doubles semifinal in Sumter, S.C. 
Harris, a senior, and Brogan, a sophomore, then placed fourth with a 6-2, 6-3 loss to a Claremont Mudd Scripps duo, junior Katie Kuosman and senior Caroline Ward. 
Men’s tennis: 
First-round singles winners at the Intercollegiate Tennis Association Atlantic Regional in Blacksburg included Old Dominion’s Michael Weindl and Jacob Nicolussi, Norfolk State’s Antonio Pejic, William and Mary junior Aidan Talcott and Hampton newcomer Matthew Foster-Estwick. 
In the second round, W&M's Scott Huang upset No. 17-32 seeded Justin Carter of Maryland Baltimore County 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 (7-1). 
The Tribe's Alec Miller upped his team-best fall singles ledger to 4-4 by bouncing George Mason's Aaron Capitel, 6-2, 6-3. Miller advanced to meet the tournament's No. 6 seed, Edoardo Tessaro of Virginia Tech, who is ranked No. 109 nationally. In doubles, Cargill and Huang continued their winning ways in doubles, dispatching NSU's Pejic and Benedikt Henning 8-4, in the second round. The Tribe duo holds a No. 9-16 seed. 
Club ice hockey: 
UNC Wilmington took the lead for good early in the third period and held on to defeat Christopher Newport 8-5 before a feisty crowd at Hampton Roads Iceplex. 
The teams will stage a rematch at 10 Sunday night. Like the game that began Friday, it will last past midnight. 
PRO HOCKEY: 
The Norfolk Admirals lost their season opener in their return to the ECHL, falling 3-0 to Wheeling before 4,243 at Scope Arena. 
The Nailers' Ty Loney, who played five games last season for the AHL Admirals, scored twice against goalie Ty Rimmer before Jarrett Burton added an empty-netter. 
Franky Palazzese made 23 saves for the Nailers, an affiliate of the Pittsburgh and Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins.
